utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Dana Perino and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City and this is "The Five." Liberals still expressing their rage that Hillary Clinton didn't win the election. Some of them screamed at the sky last night on the first anniversary of her loss.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was actually at one of those spectacles. I forgot to bring earplugs. But we're going to have more on the show about that in a moment. But you know where Hillary is today? In Wisconsin. That to lament her crushing defeat in the state she never stepped foot in once during the campaign. Last night, the failed presidential candidate broke her silence on Donna Brazile's allegation she rigged the race against Bernie, and had too much influence on the DNC. She took a dig at her party's former chair.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
utterances.utterance: I didn't know what she was referring to because as of now come out, that just wasn't the case. But the current DNC leadership really invested heavily in Virginia, and New Jersey, and other places. And I called the current chairman Tom Perez to congratulate him because he didn't get knocked off course. He didn't get overwhelmed by other narratives and stories coming out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Brazile had words of her own for the Clinton team last night. Tucker asked her about what she wrote about campaign manager Robby Mook.

utterances.speaker: TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: You said, I'm quoting, I've work with men in my life from politics and I can sense when they get to this part of about not being able to deal with a woman. Without a racial thing it was a gender thing. Every time you mention that they're trying to shut you down because you're a woman, all these guys are like no, no, no, no, no. Then sexism too apparently from your book, which is totally weird since Hillary ran a whole campaign on breaking the glass ceiling. And here's the guy running her campaign, diminishing you because of your sex. It seems ironic maybe.

utterances.speaker: DONNA BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: No, it was dismissive. Condescending and dismissive, those are the words I characterize in the book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you enjoying watching this, Kimberly Guilfoyle?

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Actually, I find it politically fascinating. I do. And I love that she's out there telling the truth. A lot of people as we know are very intimidated by the Clinton machine and their political operation that has been threatening and intimidating for so many for so many years. To the point where they went ahead and said OK, we're going to put her forward when you had really great candidates as well, like Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders going forward because she felt it was her time and it was owed to her. OK. She had her chance. So now it's time to like move on and let the party grow and express. And the only way they can kind of do that is they actually our honest about what transpired, what happened. And Donna Brazile is trying to do her level best to put that forward probably, and probably against incredible odds in the aftermath of trying to tell the truth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you on Team Donna or Team Hillary, Juan?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I don't see a need to divide them. I like them both. But I must say I do feel like.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, no. Because I think last night scream -- I feel like the 2016 election it never stops. It just goes on and on and on. And we're still arguing. You know, for the Republicans still demonizing Hillary as if she's -- I mean, I think Sean Hannity said the other day she was president. He didn't even realize she's not president.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But I'm just saying is just goes on and on with this. And now, it's got to be -- I think Donna Brazile has a legitimate thing about being condescended, not being taken seriously by Hillary's team after she stepped in to save them in terms of the DNC.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And guess what, there's a contrary argument to what Donna said because Hillary Clinton, literally, financially bailed out the DNC, the same deal had been offered to Bernie Sanders. She took it, and in exchange, she started calling the tune about who they hired and what they had to say. And Donna said, well, so it seems like it tilted things. Now Donna has gone back on the rigging claim if you notice. So, you know, but to me it's like this feeds the, I think, the Republican narrative that, oh, there's such dissension among Democrats, when in fact the big split that we know especially today, tonight, is among Republicans after what happened on Monday -- Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And we will definitely get to that later on the show, Juan. What do you think about the allegation of sexism and racism coming from Donna Brazile? You had Jen Palmeri at the top of the campaign. Huma Abedin. Does it strike you as kind of off?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: No -- I trust women when they -- they know it when they see it or they hear it. Donna Brazile is not someone who throws around allegations like that. She did a lot. She was the first African-American woman -- or maybe even the first woman to run a presidential campaign when she was the campaign chairwoman for Al Gore. And, look, she -- this is amazing to me about Democrats. This is a person who has dedicated her entire life to Democratic activist politics. When she took over for Debbie Wasserman Schultz who was disgraced and had to step down, she took a leave of absence from ABC and CNN. She did not take a salary from the DNC. And allegations that she's just trying to make money and cashing in by selling a book, that really makes me mad because if we know anything about who was actually trying to cash in, it wasn't Donna Brazile.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No. She gave up a lot of money from this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I admire her for getting out there. I do think it's not easy when you're like -- there's like shades of gray. It's like rigging or not rigging. Like probably should be a little bit more solid. But I feel like she looks liberated. And also, she has said that I worked hard to get Hillary Clinton elected. I'm excited about the Democrats going forward, but she wanted to tell her story. And when it comes to sexism, I imagine that if you're on the other end of the phone, you're in Washington, D.C., and you're getting a call from Brooklyn telling you that you know better in Brooklyn, what's going on in the country than Donna Brazile who spent her entire life on the front lines for the Democrats, it's probably pretty annoying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Perhaps.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And she's tough. I mean, she's strong, she's tough, she's been around, you know, and what she's saying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She's not a victim.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Believe me, she's not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, she's not a victim. I've had my run-ins with Donna Brazile, and she's intense. She gets her message across.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did she call you honey?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I wish he did. I'd find that flattering.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Bless your heart, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think she did. I think that was meant as a put down. I want to get Greg's take on all of this, including this when she answered whether or not she gave a question to Hillary. Roll it.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.utterance: What I sought to do was to ensure that we had these issues on the table, and I made sure that our candidate -- I didn't want them blindsided. That's what I admitted to. That's what -- what WikiLeaks put out.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: That's so good. You should do this for a living. That is hilarious.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She fed Hillary debate question and that was the excuse.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah. That was a terrible answer. I know we all love Donna now because Donna is going after Hillary. But she's got to think about a better answer for that question because it is a definite flaw. I mean, she's accusing people of rigging an election. That's a rigging right there. The only way to settle this between Hillary and Donna is in the octagon. I think Hill versus Brazile, cage match, each armed with a book, only one leaves alive. You know the thing is -- Juan, you said that we're all demonizing Hillary. You can't demonize Satan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh. And I think the fight is over before it began.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The winner of all of this is Bill because at least Hillary is yelling at somebody else. So he can relax. He's tangling with Brazile. He's tangling with a Brazile.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: it sounds like South Park. Didn't South Park put Jesus versus the devil in the octagon?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I was exaggerating. She learned her lesson. Next time, coincide your book tour with a political campaign because then there'll be a financial incentive to go to Wisconsin.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Could be. But I will say.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Working harder at this at the campaign.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I will say this in response to what Dana said that I think that what Donna did in conjunction with -- there's a -- we'll talk about it later, the new Biden book, I think lots of people are taking on the Clinton -- what was the Clinton machine which dominated Democratic party since -- was it '92.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's over.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's go to some screaming from some of Juan's friends. I've visited them last night in Washington Square Park.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you think screaming into the sky makes your side look good?

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Screaming into the sky makes our side look fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Fun?

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Funny?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How do you feel?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you feel better? Do you want a pacifier?

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did they know you're from Fox?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No. I introduced myself. Some of them ran in the opposite direction.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How many were there?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Only about 30, Gutfeld. There's more media than they were screamer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm going to say each screamer probably had their own reporter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think that that's a bad sign for Republicans because the best argument for Trump are the hysterical anti-Trump reactions. And if that's going away and everybody starts getting back to normal, you don't have that villain anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, we're keeping it alive, Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, would you like to defend Democrats on the scream fest?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought she was a wonderful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was an amazing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That was a great -- I ask you, was she a professional.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She could do horror movies.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that was pretty good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I found the whole thing embarrassing. And I'm embarrassed for myself.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. That's what I'm going to say because you had to show up and cover it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I don't think that was very cathartic for them. I think it was just too theatrical. And first of all, some of the screaming wasn't very good. It wasn't done properly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did it look like they were having a little bit of fun though?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah -- no, as Kimberly would say, cathartic experience and.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It just wasn't very many of them. I sent you an article about Philly that six people showed up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, there were three people in Philadelphia. The resistance is strong, everybody. The resistance is strong. Coming up, can Republicans get tax reform passed? New developments today on their big push, next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: After a bleak election day Tuesday for Republicans, the GOP now moving full speed ahead on the tax reform. The idea, they don't want to face an even worse prospect big losses in the midterms come 2018. The senate unveiled its own version of the overhaul this afternoon with billions of tax cuts for corporations and some for Americans. The house measure was approved earlier by the ways and means committee after some last-minute changes. Now, can Republicans finally deliver on President Trump's agenda? Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think it's going to be very difficult because now you see the party becoming even more fractured on this issue when they're not able to get consistent bandwidth and support across all areas and sort of factions of the party. And it's disappointing because we were all thinking this was going to be a big win for them. That this was a consensus building piece of legislation, a platform that they could put forth to ride into the next election to say, OK, we actually got something done. We're here about the nuts and bolts. We're with the party. It was going to be about limited government and putting more money in the pockets of the hardworking everyday men and women in this country that have been forgotten and left behind. And everyone was like, wait a second. What happen? And then you see their -- back away, taken a step back on the corporate stuff. So when you look at it, what kind of left of this carcass? And nobody's very happy with it. This is leftovers for no one, which is disappointing in my house.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg, I was going to mention to you. So President Trump called in from Asia to a group of Democrats and said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . oh, you're going to like the senate bill. Don't worry so much about the house. But I'm thinking, well, gee, if I'm a house Republican, I put myself on the line. What am I to think here?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The only positive thing I can think is that this is a work in progress.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But the reality scares me and this is why. The Democrats will never approve a bill that cuts spending or shrinks government. That will never happen. So they're never going to approve a bill that actually cuts taxes. Why is that scary? Well, Donald Trump is adamant about getting a deal done. Then that deal is going to make Democrats happy. And I don't like being in a position where, you know, I'm expected to help secure Donald Trump a victory if it goes against my principles. I mean, I'm a 2T guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm a 2T guy, terror and taxes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I thought you'll say Watters.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You'll always thinking about yourself, but it's all I've got. It's all I got. These are the two big things for me, strong on terror, strong on taxes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Me, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't move on that. This is all I have left.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: C and C and dynamite.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: C and C, that's it. All right. So now we're going to play a game, America. And in this game, Jesse Watters is going to be the house and Dana Perino will be the senate. So in the.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. You ready, guys? You're ready? You're ready? Here we go. In the house bill, all state and local tax deductions gone. What do you think, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think in the senate -- for as hard is that's going to be for many Republicans in high tax states, California, New England, New Jersey. In the senate, there are not many Republican senators in high tax states. So they don't care. And from a policy perspective, it matters more to them -- they don't think those deductions should be there at all. So I think that if you're worried about that, I think the senate is not going to do anything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Jesse, as the house and the senate version, the mortgage interest deduction is good. It stays in. So the housing industry should be pleased.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Great for the housing industry. Great for me. It's great for people in places like New York and California, but if they're going to get rid of the state and local deductions, that doesn't really balance out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because your state and local are much higher than your mortgage tax deduction. Now -- and then they're phasing in the corporate tax cuts?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. That's what I'm.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's not stimulating anything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, I was going to ask you because I saw that the top bracket, if the senate keep seven tax brackets.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, another.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. Instead of the house -- the house has four.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So they're not actually simplifying the tax code.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He went ballistic the other day when you were talking about the upper bracket. I said they went from 39 just to 38 percent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . in the senate bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Massive Reaganesque.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But there's a good reason for this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And that is because what you're talking about -- not just that the Democrats don't want to cut spending. It's that the president doesn't really want to either. Where you can actually get spending reform would be on entitlements. Even the president on the campaign trail is very adamant. I'm not going to do it. Mick Mulvaney said I've tried to convince the president, it's necessary, and he said no. So that's why they're actually trying to fit it all in this box. And I don't think it's just about winning elections for the midterms or just supporting the president's goal. I think that on the merits, tax reform makes a lot of sense. There are some really good things in here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And actually, Larry Lindsey, who is an economic tax cut expert.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, Larry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know Larry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He says that the phase-in on the corporate tax rate really wouldn't have that big of an impact. And he said that because if corporations know that it's coming, they'll be able to work with it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wall Street didn't like it today, if you look at the Dow. And you have also -- I mean, like you said, tax cut is like pizza, even if it's bad, it's still good. People are keeping -- use of the bill is OK. Tax relief is still OK. But the thing is that there are some good things in there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, there are a lot of people who will end up paying more.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Like you, and you, and you, and you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What about you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Probably. I'm not as rich as you guys.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So in the senate bill, you can deduct medical expenses, which is a big concern for seniors. But still out of there are things like teachers and school supplies, you know, moving expenses -- a lot of the expenses, things that people previously deducted, gone. So it seems to offset any potential deduct -- you're shaking your head.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm kind of -- because I feel like we've been saying forever that you get a once in a generation opportunity to reform taxes. And Republicans, conservative, for years, decades, have been saying you want a simpler, flatter, fair system. And it just feels to me like --maybe that's like, kind of in halfway, splitting a baby, maybe, but not really. And then they've got to do all these deal making. To me -- maybe it will stimulate the economy. But I wish that they would have -- just being able to do the right thing economically even though it would have been hard politically, and that is do the corporate tax rate cut and then figure out the individual stuff later because this is a mess.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's like taking half of a donkey and half of an elephant, and they go like this.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We have to go back to like Herman Cain.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And, boy, he can make some pizza too. So I'm for that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Where is he now?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Food court.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Food court, oh, my gosh. Food court meets tax cuts, exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's going to walk through that door any second. But also, there's so many people still talk about and kind of talk about the flat tax and they support the fair tax, but now this. I don't even know what happened. Like some kind of creature monster walked through the door, not what we're anticipating, and this was supposed to be their strong suit.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So quick bet because we've got to go. Does it pass?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm not feeling it tonight.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I think it's going to pass. I don't like it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Something will pass.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Gregory?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All things pass.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm hoping right now it will pass.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know this is not a happy group of Republicans. Ahead, some stunning accusations against the Republican senate nominee in Alabama. Breaking news, next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Now to a bombshell that could impact next month's special election for Jeff Sessions' old senate seat in Alabama. Some very serious new allegations against Republican nominee Roy Moore. Details from now from Peter Doocy who's live in Washington. Peter?

utterances.speaker: PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, a 53-year-old woman claims that when she was 14, and Roy Moore was just 32 -- he's 70 now, long before he became famous for getting kicked off the Alabama Supreme Court for leaving a 10 Commandment statue up. Moore kissed her, he touched her, he stripped down, he tried to get her to touch him in a sexual way, and she said she didn't want it. But tonight, Moore is not admitting to anything. He's calling this fake news. And part of an email statements from the campaign said this, Judge Roy Moore has endured the most outlandish attack on any candidate in the modern political arena. But this story is base Washington Post, alleging sexual impropriety takes the cake. National liberal organizations know their chosen candidate, Doug Jones, is in a death spiral and this is their last ditch Hail Mary. The senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, who Moore basically ran against in his primary, just said this, if these allegations are true, he must step aside. But not all Republicans have the patience to wait to see how this pans out. Senator John McCain says this about Moore, quote, he should immediately step aside and allow the people of Alabama to elect a candidate they can be proud of. But even if Moore does step aside, his name is still going to be on the ballot in December because we're within 76 days, and the law says the ballot can't be reprinted this late. Alabama also has something called a sore loser law, which means that since Luther Strange already lost this year, he can't run on the ballot as an independent. But he could stage a write-in campaign. Tonight, Strange hasn't said anything about a writing campaign. All he said is that the details he knows are very disturbing. Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. Peter, thank you for that report. So Dana, it's quite a development in a race that was heated to begin with. There's a little bit fractured in terms of Republican support with the president supporting Strange. And a bunch of other Republican, populist, Bannon, whatnot, supporting Roy Moore. This is a guy who's not gone out, you know, without a fight before when they wanted to remove him, he wouldn't resign. And now we have this situation, obviously, a very disturbing allegation. And if true, then there's no place for him on the ticket.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So the Washington Post has four on the record sources. And to call it fake news, I mean, that would be extraordinary that you had four different people all lying about somebody. These are actually Republicans, the ones that were quoted. At least the one main one is. Obviously, it's disturbing. But I have to say this, the state auditor of Alabama, the way he tried to spin this is to say take Joseph and Mary. Mary was a teenager. Joseph was an adult carpenter. They became parents of Jesus, right? As Greg pointed out, actually, Jesus was Immaculate Conception.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I remember that part.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That doesn't make sense.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I think that if you are worried about speaking up about this because you might get political ammunition to your opposing side, that that is weak and wrong.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. Greg Gutfeld, what do you make of the situation? And give us a prediction.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, I will go on record and say that I'm against adult men hitting on 14-year-old girls. OK?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Good man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Thank you for that. But it seems like it's raining bad men. You know, to paraphrase that classic song.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Raining Weinsteins?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. It seems like another hour there's another tawdry tale. And what's happening now may be a form of justice, but there seems to be missing a process. Like, what do you -- what's next now? Does -- does the guy just step down and go away? Or is there some kind of investigation?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Due process, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We seem to be -- there needs to be some kind of due process. But it also does seem to tell you that, you know, ideology often blinds you to the potential flaws in the background of somebody. You know, Luther Strange seemed like a really good guy to me, but he wasn't as ideological pure as Moore, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I -- it depends on what are you looking for.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean Trump. In terms of...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: From a conservative ideology, Luther Strange was much more pure.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, but I'm talking in the...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In the new version of populism.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: In the new ideology. Yes. In the new -- we've replaced one ideology with another.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. GUTFELD; Is what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You mean that the -- he was more about Steve Bannon guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, right. And so that made you blind.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Luther Strange was much more a Mitch McConnell guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And now -- and Bannon, in fact, just said yesterday, "Get McConnell out of here" and all that. But this is Steve Bannon's guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's -- my point is when you choose an ideology, which is like this is how it's going to be, you often -- you don't really do as much research as you should, because you're blinded by your own biases.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, so also, Jesse, you have McConnell speaking out, saying if these allegations are true, he must step aside. So you've already got division, you know, in the party. How do you see this playing out and how quickly?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't see how this plays out.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Luther could be a write-in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It feels kind of gross talking about the political implications of this, because if these allegations are true, I feel horrible for these women. It's disgusting. Even just the allegation itself, it's not just one person. It's multiple people. So the whole cloud, the whole stench around this guy, I don't see how he can represent Alabama in the U.S. Senate.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He won't even be available (ph) for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Politics is a dirty business. And you know, innocent until proven guilty, but this doesn't seem like that to me. I'm just not getting that feeling. So I think he should step down, do the decent thing. But I mean, to your point about the politics of this, I shouldn't even say it, but I mean, the Democrats obviously are going to capitalize on it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, FOX had it -- and this is a little bit back -- but I think FOX had the race about even. Some people have...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, just last week.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So some people had, though, Moore up a little bit. But the problem here is that Roy Moore's base is the evangelical community. And I know, you know, for people like me, I think, how do the evangelicals support Donald Trump? But how are they going to deal with this? Because this is rank hypocrisy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: These allegations, I don't think that's even within the realm.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. Grabbing women and stuff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's what I was saying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But this is much more. This is -- is that what your point is, that this is...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not the same. I'm talking about...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Correct. I agree with you. But I'm saying for evangelicals, this is a real test. And Alabama, in the Bible Belt, this is going to be a difficult issue.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I just don't -- I don't know where it goes. You know, I'm assuming that The Washington Post will have a follow-up story, and if Roy Moore has evidence that this is, indeed, fake news, that he should come forward with it, all of it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, usually with these stories, another story encourages other people to talk.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Which is why it's raining bad men.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Hate when that happens. Coming up, Greg exposes the truth about some race-related hoaxes coming up next. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now on to some lighter news: A few months back, we ran a clip of a superintendent at the Air Force Academy chastising racist cadets. His speech came after slurs were found on a dorm room message board belonging to black students.

utterances.speaker: LT. GEN. JAY SILVERIA, AIR FORCE ACADEMY SUPERINTENDENT
utterances.utterance: If you demean someone in any way, then you need to get out. And if you can't treat someone from another race or a different color skin with dignity and respect, then you need to get out. The power of that diversity comes together and makes us that much more powerful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, like many in the media, we ran this clip because it provided a powerful response to racism that the media demanded after Charlottesville. While the clip ran, I kept shaking my head for I'd seen this story before. The list of hate crimes hoaxes is long. Now we must add this one to the tally. According to The Air Force Times, a black cadet admitted to writing the slurs and he's since left the school. So what's the response when we see stories like these exposed as hoaxes? It's never as huge as the initial response was when we assumed that it was real -- which only encourages more hoaxes, for the outrage over the crime is the only part the press seems to remember, not its debunking, which encourages the copycats. Which is why we're doing this now: So people don't keep thinking this kind of thing pays off. Of course, social justice warriors will repeat the pathetic excuse that, while this racist act may not be true here, you just know it's true somewhere else. Which guarantees further opportunity for attention and likely another student's expulsion. I know it's crazy, but maybe it's time we stop feeding the stories to the public before they're properly investigated. Who am I kidding? All right, Juan, I think you owe me a steak dinner, because I remember after we did this, I said to you, "This isn't real."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You did say that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You guys are making dinner bets on hate crimes?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's because we're so compassionate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think -- well, I first -- my head was...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You shake your head, but you have this thing where you're just like...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm going, "This is not true. This is not true." And then afterwards, I go, "Juan, steak dinner. I'm betting."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, it's not good for you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's not good for you, yes. I was going nuts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think we'll give you fish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't eat fish. You know that. So what do you -- when you see this, this obviously puts race relations back. Because it makes everybody suspicious of accusations now, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Sure. But you know, I think the reason that you're doing this is that you think that this means that all allegations are somehow fraught. I don't think that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're using that social justice...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm asking.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I'm saying I told you so, Juan. That's why I'm doing it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In this case, you tell me so, and there are other cases, because as you were speaking, as you were building the monologue, I think the viewers can see...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's a lot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: ... there's a list of people. But my -- my feeling about this is, look, if you ever look at my -- or at the Twitter account for this show while I'm on, you will know that there are some pretty harsh feelings...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Don't look at it, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Most of those, though, are from Kilmeade. So -- Kilmeade's got a lot of dummy accounts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, now that Twitter's 280, it's really bad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He spends a lot of time on it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's a terrible person. He gets up so early, and then he just goes on after Juan. Kimberly, is there some kind of punishment that -- is, like the punishment so -- a lot of times when people do these fake hoaxes, if they say they're under psychological stress, they need therapy. Should there be stiffer penalties for this stuff?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I mean, you would think so, right? Because when you see kind of the cumulative effect and the collateral damage that results from things like this, it's really bad. Remember, "Hands up. Don't shoot"? It really stimulates in a very negative way, you know, racial divide and injustice and crimes that are committed against individuals, personal and property damage. Really hurting communities. And it's so far along after, sometimes when you find out that this wasn't true, that if you didn't sort of search for it to follow up on it, you wouldn't know. And that's why I think you did a great job...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: ... on this one thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That you actually bring it up and you follow up and you track it down and say, "Remember this? When I was like, 'Hey, this wasn't true.'"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I knew it was going to happen. Another hate crime that was exposed as a hoax, it was, Dana, a Kansas State student wrote slurs on his car. And it turned out it was the victim, a black male, who had written it. And so, when you hear the initial...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did he have to leave the school?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I didn't read that far.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He wasn't in the school.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When it comes to this person from the Air Force Academy...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, he's gone.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: ... the punishment is that he just missed out on a wonderful educational opportunity.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And so...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Does he deserve a second chance?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't think so?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm not -- but I also think that this should not take away from what I think was a pretty amazing display of leadership on behalf of Jay Silveria, the lieutenant general who addresses the students immediately, takes immediate action with a pretty powerful speech.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why? Are you going to take away from that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I just am. Because I knew it was fake. And you know what, I can't...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But he didn't know it was fake, and he felt like he had to do something immediately.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or was he trying to make -- cover his...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Are you questioning the lieutenant general?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I question everything. I question you right now, Dana. I don't even know who you are anymore. Jesse, thoughts?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thoughts, yes. Well, I think Kimberly's favorite poet, Shakespeare, said a lie travels halfway around the world before truth puts its shoes on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think Shakespeare said that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that a hoax?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think it was Jim Fix (ph). I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Either way, this happens. And this guy researching this says there's hundreds of these per year. We just had one in New York where a Muslim woman said, "Two white guys on the subway attacked me and tried to rip off my hijab."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She had a...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ended up filing a fake police report. Now, the motivation for this is because people are struggling with personal problems, and they want to feel, as the victim...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Important.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And they want the attention that the victim and victimhood gets. And the victimology industry is an incubator for these fake hate crimes, and they're mostly on college campuses, where you have these safe spaces, the micro aggressions, and everybody hates the straight white male. So when these people get to college, their antennas go up, and they're always looking for sexism and homophobia and racism. And then, when nothing happens, they are forced to make them up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Instead of being a victim, be a victor. There's a T-shirt for you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was Shakespeare, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was Shakespeare, too. Maybe it was. I don't know. Maybe it was Shakespeare. I don't think it was.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We'll find out in the commercial break.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. A new twist in the violent attack on Kentucky Senator Rand Paul, next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Early reports were Senator Rand Paul was assaulted by neighbor Rene Boucher because of a landscaping disagreement. That resulted in six broken ribs and fluid around the lungs for Senator Paul. But now the senator suggests the landscaping dispute claim is erroneous, and a statement from his senior advisors, Doug Stafford, says, quote, "This was not a fight. It was a blindside, violent attack by a disturbed person. Anyone claiming otherwise is uninformed or seeking media attention." Senator Paul's neighbor has pleaded not guilty, but sources say Senator Paul has been told to expect federal charges against his attacker. What's the federal charges? Is it because he's a senator?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, and so here's the thing. So when you have an investigation like this being conducted by the FBI, you're not supposed to talk about it. He shouldn't be making any statement, because this is a very serious matter. He was injured in a horrific way. He was attacked by a psycho coward who blindsided him and severely injured him. So it's a bad situation. And when people say, "Oh, he's not issuing a statement." I mean, to suggest, like -- can you imagine if this was a liberal Democrat and somebody came and attacked him at his house and broke his ribs and fluid in the lungs and the whole deal? No. It would be a completely different way that this would be handled. And for them to try to say it was about bushes or foliage or whatever, it's just absolutely ridiculous. I see this in the same way that I saw the attacks on the baseball game where, you know, Scalise was injured. This appears to be that somebody who's well-documented -- well-documented -- on his Facebook page as somebody who is very much against President Trump, wants impeachment, is very liberal in his ideology and committed a crime specifically, I believe, against Rand Paul because of those ideals.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It did seem a bit bizarre that the statements coming out initially were about rules and regulations in the neighborhood about what you can plant and what you can't plant. Like pumpkins are not allowed or something like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I don't -- I can't -- I don't know what to make of this. I mean, it's interesting how, you know, the closer you are to somebody, the more likely you don't like them. It's like -- it's like, why do anchors hate each other on shows when they only see each other an hour a day? You know what I mean? It's like these neighbors -- they always say good fences make good neighbors. Maybe they didn't have good fences. But there might be...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You can't excuse this guy's behavior. It's completely...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not saying that. I'm just saying there's something else going on here that we don't know about. And what would make me so angry to attack somebody and just -- we assume -- we keep saying he's unstable. We don't know if he's unstable. But what would make me angry to attack -- to go and attack a neighbor, that's what you should be asking yourself. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, what do you think? Will we ever really no?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Typical liberal, always blaming the bushes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Aaa! Well done! Well done.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I knew Gutfeld would have liked that one. Just like Gutfeld, I sniffed this out. When I heard the guy's name was Rene Boucher, I was like guilty as charged.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, really?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Also, here's the deal. CNN put this thing out from the beginning. They did a report immediately afterwards that talked to a few anonymous neighbors that blamed the landscaping. No one was on the record blaming landscaping. And then the Washington Examiner came out with seven on-the-record neighbors saying this guy had nothing to do with the bushes. It was all political. And then the real story got out. And they also bought, the media, the defense attorney's lying about this just being about landscaping. When have the media ever bought a line from a defense attorney so some guy that just assaulted someone? And Kimberly's point is good. If Crying Chuck got clotheslined from behind on the New York City subway, that would be a national story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why don't do it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: These things can be mysterious. I'm not saying this was sane (ph). But remember when Senator Reid got all -- and that never actually -- no one ever actually understood. He said he was doing exercises.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He got hit.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Fell off of a machine.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, a rubber band thing in the bathroom.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You bought that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, not necessarily. But Juan, I mean, is there -- do you think that we will get resolution on this?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think you've got to. Because it's going to go to some kind of a trial. And I think it's going to go. Right now it's a misdemeanor charge. It sounds like it's going to get ramped up, because it's going to be an attack on a federal official.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's going to go federal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I must say I don't see why anybody who is anti-Trump would be attacking Rand Paul.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's what I don't get.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It doesn't make sense to me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. "One More Thing" up next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You know they talk on the phone every...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're so mean. You're the meanest person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Time now for "One More Thing" -- Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Let's go to this thing, real quick.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Greg's Etiquette News.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, this thing, it's been a kind of a gloomy news day. If this doesn't make you smile, nothing will. Check out this otter eating at a dinner table.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think there's anything better on the planet then watching this otter, a domestic Asian short-clawed otter, eating with his hands at the dinner table like a normal child.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Aww.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What good manners! He has better manners than I do. Look at him with his hands. This is amazing. This is -- this animal has a soul.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is the most uplifting part of the show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, now you know why I'm happy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Mine is even better. Thank you so much. So take a look at this adorable video. This shows President Trump showing the Chinese president video of his granddaughter singing in Mandarin. And this is Arabella, so take a look.

utterances.speaker: ARABELLA KUSHNER, GRANDDAUGHTER OF DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: (SINGING IN MANDARIN)

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Can't say that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. And President Xi said that she did a terrific job and deserved an A-plus. She is 6 years old, and she is the daughter of Ivanka and Jared. She's been learning Mandarin from her Chinese nanny. Isn't that great?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Cute little hair bun. Adorable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Cute.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And effective diplomacy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I mean, the best.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: My turn?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. So Veterans Day is coming up on Sunday. And so veterans, pay attention, because this is a pretty good deal. There's a company called, "We Work." And they have high-tech, fully operational workplaces, and they are starting something called Veterans and Residents. So through the program, every six months for the next five years, they're going to sponsor work space for 100 veterans across ten cities. Lots of great cities on this. They have on-site counseling. They can help you get your business started. And they have also committed to hiring 1,500 veterans themselves over the next five years to support all of their business -- it's a growing company. And you can go to WeWork.com, Veterans and Residents, to learn more. I think it's a really good deal, and I would take advantage of it, vets.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We love the vets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So for the first four days, Obamacare enrollment through the roof. Americans registering on Tuesday. Health care proved to be one of the most important issues, as you know, in Virginia. Maine voters also strongly support expanding Medicaid under Obamacare. And now look at this. Here's Jimmy Kimmel promoting I don't know what, but he's promoting something, very -- called Trumpcare.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I just found out about Trumpcare.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I just found out about Trumpcare, too.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: My family got coverage we can afford, thanks to Trumpcare.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Trumpcare is the market-based insurance program administered by President Trump that meets his campaign promise for great affordable care.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's the message for politicians. Americans want good health care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Steve Scalise still recovering from being shot. He was racing his scooter through the halls of Congress with his fellow congressman, Representative Johnson from Texas, who actually was wearing a helmet. I'm not really sure why. But we don't know who won yet. They were taking bets on the side, we have learned. But good luck, and I'm glad Steve is back. All right. "Special Report" up next.
